Badger bits nake helpers.

Contains common nake helpers.

Imports

nake, os, bb_system, osproc, parseopt, rdstdin, strutils, tables, sequtils, algorithm, md5

Types

Shell_failure* = object of EAssertionFailed
  errors*: string

Indicates something failed, with error output if errors is not nil.

Raised by test_shell().

Consts

sybil_witness* = ".sybil_systems"
Special witness filename used sometimes to hide nake developer commands. 
dist_dir* = "dist"
Directory where final binaries are placed for collection. 
vagrant_linux_dir* = "vagrant_linux"
Directory were vagrant configuration files and vm instances are stored. 
zip_exe* = "zip"
Name of the platform specific command used to create zip files. 
software_dir* = "software"
Name of the directory used to communicate with vagrant instances. 
nimcache_dir* = "nimcache"
Name of the nimcache directory.

Procs

proc cp*(src, dest: string)

Verbose wrapper around os.copyFileWithPermissions().

In addition to copying permissions this will create necessary destination directories. If src is a directory it will be copied recursively.

proc test_shell*(cmd: varargs[string, `$`]): bool {.discardable.}
Like nake's direShell() but doesn't system.quit(), instead raises Shell_failure. 
proc copy_vagrant*(dest: string)

Copies the current git files to dest/software_dir.

The files to copy are found out with git ls-files -c. The sybil_witness witness will be created at dest.

proc build_vagrant*(vagrant_dir, remote_shell_commands: string)

Powers up the vagrant box in the specified dir to run some commands.

Use this to run system commands to build the binaries in the vagrant machine. The remote_shell_commands parameter is meant to be a string that will be embedded inside a shell command, so you can run several commands with &&. Example:

build_vagrant("dir", "nake test && nimble build && nake install")

Alternatively you can pass a multiline string, where each newline will be replaced with double ampersands. Equivalent example:

build_vagrant("dir", """
  nake test
  nimble build
  nake install""")

The commands will be run in the /vagrant/software_dir directory, populated previously by copy_vagrant(). After all work has done the vagrant instance is halted. This doesn't do any provisioning, the vagrant instances are meant to be prepared beforehand.

proc run_vagrant*(remote_shell_commands: string; dirs: seq[string] = nil)

Takes care of running some shell commands in the specified vagrant dirs.

Pass the directories where vagrant bootstrap files are to be copied. If you pass nil, the proc will iterate over all the directories found under vagrant_linux_dir. The remote_shell_commands is the shell string to be run for each vm, see build_vagrant().

proc pack_dir*(zip_dir: string; do_remove = true)

Creates a zip out of zip_dir, then optionally removes that dir.

The zip will be created in the parent directory with the same name as the last directory plus the zip extension.

proc collect_vagrant_dist*()

Takes dist generated files from vagrant dirs and copies to our dist_dir.

This requires that both vagrant' and current dist_dirs exists.

proc switch_to_gh_pages*()

Forces changing git branch to gh-pages and running gh_nimrod_doc_pages.

This is a potentially destructive action!

proc switch_back_from_gh_pages*()
Counterpart of switch_to_gh_pages. 
proc show_md5_for_github*(templ: string)

Computes md5 for files in dist_dir.

The output will be displayed in a markdown template which includes the current git commit hash. To obtain the nim commit a git command is run in the parent root directory, which should point to the current compiler checkout. The following positional strings can be used in templ:

  • nim git commit (if possible).
proc run_test_subdirectories*(test_dir: string)

Compiles and runs files in the specified test directory.

Inside the test_dir you need to have separate directories for each test, and each of these directories has to have a test*.nimrod.cfg file, which will be used to compile and run the test. If any of the tests fails this proc will quit.

Templates

template glob*(pattern: string): expr
Familiar os.walkFiles() shortcut to simplify getting lists of files.
